div.p: A DIRECTORY TO CHRISTIAN PERFECTION.
Wherein severall Considerations, Cautions and Advises are set downe for the perfecting of the Saints, and for the completing of them in the knowledge of Christ Jesus.

q.p: Praying exceedingly that wee might see your face, and might perfect that which is lacking in your faith.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by Matthew Simmons dwelling in Aldersgate-streete next dore to the Gilded Lyon. 1650.

div.head: A DIRECTORY To Christian Perfection.

q.p: Bee yee therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in Heaven is perfect.

div.p: A Malicious Christian and a courteous Cynicke, are expressions equally including contradiction, yet notwithstanding it is too manifest that thousands that honour themselves with the name of Christians, that dishonour God, and by their workes deny their very name; for if the least injury be offered them either in word or in deed, though in passion, how doe they soame and rage, like the troubled Sea, while they are revenged of the injury: But our Saviour here doth abundantly condemne and give rules to the contrary, from verse 43. to the end of the Chapter. A briefe exposition whereof shall serve both for the prosecution of the point, and introduction to the Text. In the 43. verse our Saviour sayes, That you have heard that it hath been said, Thou shalt love thy neighbour, and hate thine enemy: our Saviour does not say that ever it was said so; for there is nor any place in Scripture where wee are commanded to hate our enemy; and there are three things wherein their glosse is faulty.
First is, that they restraine the word Neighbour, to one of their own kindred or Nation, which our Saviour fully confutes in the tenth of Luke in the parable of the good Samaritan.
Secondly, they leave out, as thy selfe.

Thirdly, they put in, thou shalt hate thine enemy; whereas there is nothing in the Scripture for it, but many places against it: Exodus the 23. ver. 4, 5. If thou meetest thine enemies Oxe or his Asse going astray, thou shalt surely bring it hacke to him againe. If thou seest the Asse of him that hateth thee lying under his burden & wouldest forbeare to help him, thou shalt surely help with
him. And whereas some say it was to be meant of an Israelite, if he be an enemy, but not of those of other Nations, but that they might hate them; the contrary is evident, Deut. 10. ver. 19. Love yee therefore the strangers, for yee were strangers in the land of Egypt.

Ʋse. The use of this is, That every one should read the Word of God, for if he onely heares the Word and searches not the Scripture, he shall heare that many things are said in the Word of God, which are no where there to be found, but divers times the cleane contrary.

Argu: So the first argument against revenge is that from the Alpha and beginning of Genesis, to the Omega and Amen of the Revelations; there is not one syllable to warrant us in such practises, but they are diametrically opposite to the doctrine of the Gospel, as you have it in the next verse; But I say unto you, as if Christ should say, whatsoever thoughts your own corruption suggests unto you, or whatsoever men shall say unto you it matters not, they are likely enough to blow the least sparke of contention into a flame, they haply will tell you that if you beare one injury you invite another. But I say unto you love your enemies, besides there is an Emphasis in the words, I and you; for it hath the same force to move us to love our enemies, Matth. 18. ver. 33. He that hath loved us and gave himselfe for us when wee were his enemies, may he not justly expect and command from us that wee should love our enemies, that wee should forgive an hundred pence when he commands us so to doe that hath forgiven us ten thousand talents. But to the further exposition of the following words, wee are to love our enemies, be they never so many wee must love them all, and be they never so much ones enmies, for here is no limitation put either in respect of their number or enmity, or in respect of our love; it is not said how much wee should love them, to shew that wee should love them without measure.

Reas. Now the reason why love your enemies is put first, is because that this must have an influence upon all the rest, wee must blesse them that curse us, doe good to them that hate us, upon this very ground, and from this principle, because wee love them.

But if our enemies curse us, then wee are not to content our selves with a bare inward love to them, but wee must shew our love by our outward expressions; and as our enemies encrease in the manifestations of their enmity, so wee must encrease in the manifestations of our love, and wee must not onely not curse againe, or be silent, and neither blesse nor curse, but wee must blesse them that curse us, nor is it set downe how much, how often, nor when wee must blesse, that wee might put no limits to our blessing in any of these respects: and as before it is observed concerning our enemies, be they never so many, and never so much our enemies, you ought to love them; for the same observations may runne thorough all the rest of the branches of this precept, nor doth our Saviour wish us to reprove those that curse us, but to blesse them.
First, Because reproofes at such a time are very unseasonable; for doubtlesse there is a time to reprove.
Secondly, Generally because reproofes at such times when people are cursing of us, are a kinde of revenge taken of them, especially, if it be before others, for wee lay open their shame.

Thirdly, Because this is the mildest, the secretest, and lovingest way of reproofe; for I remember the rule is given that one should not, if one heares one speake a word of Latine wrong, tell him that he pronounces it not as it should be pronounced, much lesse to tell him that he is an Ignorant man, but speedily to take some occasion to speake that word right; so here, if thine enemy speake false Christian language, thy mildest way to shew him his errour, is by speaking those words right which he hath spoke wrong; for by thy blessing him thou doest in a milde manner shew that he should have blessed thee.

The next branch is, that wee should doe good to them that hate us, many are willing to give good words, but they will not doe any good deeds to their enemies, they will serve God of that which cost them nought; but in the Originall it is not doe good to them that hate you, but doe well; to shew us that if wee doe our enemy good, yet if wee doe it in a churlish and scornfull manner, wee doe not observe this commandement: But if thine enemy shall have blocked up this way, because he scornes to receive, or by reason of his persecution hath disabled thee to bestow any temporall courtesie upon him, then take another way, and doe him that courtesie which he cannot reject; for though one cannot give a man money who will not receive it, yet one may pray, and ones prayers may be powerfull to doe our enemies good whether they will or no, so that thou canst never be so impoverisht by persecution, but thou art worth a prayer; nor thine enemy can hardly be so obstinate, but thy prayers may fasten blessings on him, doe thine enemy as much good as thou canst, and what thou canst not doe, desire God to doe for him. It follows, that yee may be the Children of your Father.

First it is not meant as if wee could love our enemies before wee were Gods children, or that this is the way to get adoption or regeneration, for he calls God their Father when he wishes them to doe thus that they may be his children; therefore the meaning may be thus: First, that you may be, id est, that you may be knowne to be both to your selves and others; as it is said, Wee are justified by works, id est, our justification is knowne to our selves and others by workes; or so that you may be children, is meant, that since two wayes wee are the children of God by adoption and sanctification; in respect of sanctification wee may have the image of God renewed more and more in us, and so in a qualified sense may be said more to be Gods children, and in that sense wee may attaine to be more the children of God, id est, more like him.
Secondly, None can be the children of God unlesse they love their enemies.
Thirdly, That every one should strive both to be and to know himselfe to be the childe of God.

Fourthly, That no man by nature is the childe of God, since no man
by nature can or does love his enemy, as it follows, which is in Heaven.
First, Wee can never love our enemies so long as wee are no more then the children of our earthly father.
Secondly, That it is an heavenly thing to love ones enemies, and therefore ex diametro an hellish thing to hate ones friends, and therefore to hate Gods people.
First, Because they are our friends.
Secondly, They are heavenly.
Thirdly, This is the first Motive to perswade to love, &c. And as it followes; For he makes his Sunne to arise.

First, This is that second Motive to the duty, id est, Gods Example, and it stands thus; If God who is greater then you does bestow greater blessings upon those that are greater enemies, and between whom and him there is a greater distance, how much more should you love, &c?

Secondly, The Sunne doth not arise of it selfe, that knows not what it does; nor is it of necessitie that the Sunne should arise; of necessitie, it is in respect of the Sunne, not in respect of God, for he makes it to arise, so that the Sunne cannot choose but arise, but God might choose whether he would make it arise.
Thirdly, These common blessings come not by chance as well as not by necessitie, it is by Gods providence that wee enjoy them.

Fourthly, It shews the continuall concurrence and power of God with naturall causes, it is not like a Clocke which when it is once wound up will goe of it selfe by the weight, but as a pen that writes not without the continuall guidance of the Writer; so God did not at the first create the World, Sunne, &c. and so without his actuall concurrence to every particular act enable them to doe it, so that the Sunne did not arise at the first moment of its creation more immediately by the power and providence of God, then it does now, this advances Gods goodnesse; for as one that hath setled maintenance upon an Hospitall for the poore, it argues not so much patience in him, to suffer the men there if they abuse him to receive their setled stipend, as it does for him daily to feed them with his own hand, and to put money into one of their hands, while the other is listed up against him.

Fifthly, Or may not, he make it, be taken in this sense? that all the creatures of God are enemies to the wicked; the earth will not beare them, but open her mouth and swallow them, the sire will not warme them, but consume them, the Sunne will not give light unto them, as it did once in Egypt, while they had light in Goshen, but God, as it were, renuente sole, doth make it arise upon the good and the bad; it shews the great power of God, that not onely the things on earth, but all the creatures in heaven and earth obey him, he that can make the Sunne arise, what can he not doe. Neh. 9.6. As it follows; His Sunne to arise.
First, A sortiori, it is a Motive to us to doe good to our enemies.

Reas. First, Because that which wee give or bestow on them in respect of God, wee have no right to, wee are but his Stewards, and what have
wee that wee have not received; wee have the possession of all those things wee have, but not the disposing of them: in respect of the poore to give them almes is charity, in respect of God it is justice. But you see here the Sunne is called his Sunne, he hath a full title to it: if he therefore gives that which is his own, and is Lord of, much more should wee deliver that, of which wee are onely Stewards, when he that is the Lord commands us.

Secondly, Consider what he gives; it is his Sunne the greatest of all temporall blessings in the world, for wee might longer live without food or rayment, then wthout the benefit of the Sunne; for without his heat all things would immediately freeze to death: nay, not onely by giving the wicked the benefit of the Sunne, they enjoy that heat which is necessary for life, but they enjoy the light of the Sunne, which is a thing of ornament and pleasure, to make their life comfortable, Eccle. 11.7. Therefore if God gives the wicked things of ornament, much more give your enemy bread, Rom. 12.20. No man not onely cannot, but doth not offer to lay claime to the Sunne: and as it follows, on the good and the bad: some will say, how can it be otherwise, for if the Sunne shines upon the good, how can it but shine upon the bad also, since they are in one Kingdome, in one Towne, in one house? but God is not necessitated to bestow this mercy upon the bad, though he bestowes it upon the good; For de facto God did make it darke in Egypt when it was light for three dayes in Goshen, though they were of the same Kingdome; the cloud gave light to the Israelites in their March, and at the same time was darknesse to the Egyptians, Exod. 14.19, 20. Besides, God can strike all wicked men with blindnesse, so that the Sunne shall be in respect of his light, as if it was not to them, and he might strike them with such a burning feaver as he threatens, Deut. 28.22. that for its heat the Sunne should be worse to them, then if it was not, and thousand other wayes knowne to the Lord.
Secondly, Wee see that by common and temporall blessings, the good are not distinguished from the bad.

Thirdly, It followes that wicked and unjust men are Gods enemies, and curse God, hate God, persecute God, and despitefully use him, or else it would not follow from this example of Gods dealing with wicked men that wee should love our enemies, &c. For one might say, it is true, God makes his Sonne to shine upon the bad and unjust, but though indeed they be Gods enemies, yet they doe not hate him, curse, &c. as mine doe me.
Thirdly, That God may be said to blesse, and doe good to those that are bad and unjust, Deut. 10.17. Acts 14.17. And as it followes; He sendeth raine.

First, God bestowes not one but many blessings upon the wicked, he doth not onely make the Sunne to arise, but sends also the raine upon them; nay by bestowing this second blessing, he takes off that inconvenience which otherwise would follow upon the enjoyment of the first, nay they doe helpe mutually one another; for the raine cooles the heat of
the Sunne, and the Sunne warmes the coolenesse of the raine, and both together make the earth fruitfull: from hence wee may learne.
First, To doe great and many benefits to our enemies.
Secondly, Not to doe them such courtesies that wee know will bring mischiefes upon them, and to doe them good in one thing, on purpose to doe them hurt in another.

Thirdly, Wee should doe good to those that doe not onely thanke us for courtesies, but attribute it to others, for God does so, he makes his Sunne to shine, and his raine to fall, not onely upon those that are so bad as not to be thankfull for them, but are so exceeding unjust as not to account God the Author of them. The observations concerning Gods making the Sunne to arise, &c. Mutatis mutandis, may agree to this latter part of the verse; this may also be observed, that God doth not onely give temporall blessings to those that aske and come for them, but he sends his mercies home to their very doores; for the clouds that arise from the Sea, or other places, he causes his winds to carry them to their habitations. Besides, this may be observed, that one reason why our Saviour instances in these blessings rather then in others, may be, not onely the reasons before, but this also, that wee might never want a Motive to our doing good to our enemies; for whether it raines, or shines, wee have either the instance of Gods making his Sunne to shine, or his raine to fall upon wicked men; as it followes, upon the just and unjust.

First, It is not set downe here as contradistinguished, as if there were some bad that were not unjust, and some unjust that were not bad, nor is it meant God makes his Sunne to arise on the bad, and sends his raine upon the unjust, bestowes some kinde of these blessings upon some wicked, and the other kinde upon other wicked men, but he bestowes both upon all; as before it is not meant wee should love our enemies, but not love those that curse us, or blesse those that cursed us, but not blesse those that hate us; but as when God commands us to blesse them that curse us, and does not say, doe good to them that curse you, it is because blessing is directly opposed to cursing; and so it is more likely to make him that curses see his errour, because contraries being placed one by another, make each other more apparent, as it is before shewen, and as it followes; for if yee love them that love you: The former argument was from the example of Allmighty God, whom all confesse in all things to doe well; there he brings an argument from them whom all condemne, and the argument stands thus; you all desire and expect to be rewarded for your workes, but none of you thinke that the Publicanes shall have any reward, therefore neither you, if you love them that onely love you, for so doe they.
Secondly, It is good to make use of that evill opinion wee have of others, as a Motive to our selves to be better.

Thirdly, That the wickedest man may have something good in him, but nothing perfect, and as it followes, What reward have yee? Christ doth not set it downe positively, that they have no reward, but by way
of Question to shew them that it is not onely his judgement, but their owne, for he appeales to their owne consciences, and it shewes the manifestnesse of the truth, since selfe love doth cast such a mist before our eyes when wee are to judge of things concerning our selves, that except the truth doth shine very bright wee cannot behold it; it is not said, what great reward, but what reward, to shew them that they should be so farre from expecting everlasting life, that they cannot expect any reward at all.
Thirdly, It is not said, what reward shall yee have, but what have yee to shew that they are not to expect so much as a temporall reward for loving their friends.

Fourthly, They have temporall blessings as Motives to obedience, but none by way of reward for obedience; for it is not said, what blessings, but what reward have you; for if one say of your righteousnesse you doe, doe not the Publicans the same? one may say of your blessings, have not the Publicans the same? Doe not even the Publicans the same? The Publicans were such as used to receive custome, tribute-money, and other taxes, and were men very odious to the Jewes, both for their injustice and oppression of them, and they were generally Heathens, because the Jewes did abhorre to have any hand in the oppressing of their owne Nation; nay, our Saviour joynes them with Harlots, Sinners, Heathens; and if you salute your brethren onely, the word translated salute, signifies to kisse and embrace; and our Saviour doth signifie by it all outward expressions of love.
Secondly, By Brethren is meant our neare kindred and acquaintance.
Thirdly, This word onely is to be referred as well to the former verse as to this; and the observations mutatis mutandis upon that may be applyed to this.
In the handling of these words, I shall shew these things.
First, How wee must be perfect as our Father which is in Heaven is perfect.
Secondly, In the pressing of Christian perfection, three things I shall set downe. First, Severall Considerations. Secondly, Severall Cautions. Thirdly, Severall Rules or Advises.

Before I come to the Exposition of the words, to shew how wee must be perfect as our Father which is in Heaven is perfect, I must remove an Objection that quarrells against the perfection of this rule of perfection; viz. First, That this rule is too high: Secondly, It is dangerous: Thirdly, That it is imperfect and too short.

First, It is too high, for what man or Angel is able to be as perfect as God, it is not compatible to any created nature, for that being finite cannot possibly be capable of infinite perfection, for his glorious Name is exalted above all blessing and praise, Neh. 9.5. And the Lord is faine to dwell in thicke darknesse, and thereby doth connivere radios suae gloriae, and the Angells also doe cover their faces with their wings, or else they, were not able to behold his glory, their understanding would be dazled
if therefore they are not able to behold his glory in its full strength and vigour, how much lesse are they able to attaine it? how much lesse able are wee that are sinfull dust and ashes, who are not able to behold (that which is darknesse in comparison of God) the Sunne, to be perfect as God is perfect?

First, I answer, That wee are here commanded to attaine the same kinde, not the same degrees of perfection: it is not be as perfect as your Father, but be perfect as your Father; wee are to goe in the same steps, though not aequis passibus, his example is the coppy wee should write by, though it be impossible to write so curious an hand, yet wee may write the same words, &c.

Secondly, It is an advantage to have so perfect a copy set us, though wee cannot attaine it, for who is there that learnes to write, that blames the exactnesse of the copy he writes by? And he that taketh aime and shooteth at the highest point or zenith of the Heaven, will shoote higher with the same strength then he that shoots at a levell, or any other point besides.
Thirdly, It addes to the holinesse of any action that wee desire in that action to be like to God, and upon that ground to desire to be holy because God is holy.

Secondly, You may say, it is a dangerous rule, for wee may not strive to be like unto God in many things, wee may not desire our own glory as he doth; Adam desiring to be like him, it was his sinne and his fall. I answer to that, that there are two kinds of perfections in God communicable and incommunicable, incommunicable are called those, not which the creature cannot have, but which the creature ought not to have, as to doe all things for its own glory; for a creature may doe all things for its own glory, but it ought not so to doe, not onely because it is folly in the creature to doe so, for glory is a thing of ornament, and man is a poore creature that wants things necessary, and it was folly for man to buy Jewells to adorne him, while he was ready to starve for want of garments to cloath him; but it is because it is incommunicable to the creature, that is, God and the creature cannot doe things for their owne glory without thwarting one another, for If man doe things for his owne glory, then it must needs follow that he doth it not for the glory of God, and so thwarts the end that God proposeth to himselfe, and to all creatures, viz. his own glory: so that here when our Saviour commands us to be perfect as he is perfect, it is meant that wee should endeavour to attaine those perfections which our having doth not hinder his having of them, as holinesse, patience, wisdome, &c. for our holinesse be it never so great makes not God lesse holy, but the more wee seeke our own glory, the more wee rob God of his.

Secondly, I answer, that all these kinds of perfections which are incommunicable, are rather resultancies and consequences of perfection, then perfections, for it is more proper to say, that because God is infinitely perfect, therefore all the heaven and earth should praise him; then
to say because heaven and earth doth praise him, therefore he is infinitely perfect; for the praises which are given unto him are not the causes of his perfection, but his infinite perfections are the causes of his praise.
Thirdly, It may be objected, that it is an imperfect rule, for it seemes to come short.
First, In respect of our relations, as of husband, wife, childe, subject, how can wee have an example of God in these particulars, since he is not capable of these relations?
Secondly, In respect of duties, we are to pray, to worship, to heare the Word.
Thirdly, In respect of graces, repentance, faith, hope, patience in afflictions; all these are below him.

I answer; First, That though wee have not an example of any of these, from God considered in himselfe, yet wee have of most of these from Christ who was God as well as Man, for wee have an example, how to carry our selves in afflictions, of obedience both to God and man, and those relations which our Saviour left us no example of in a temporall way, yet in a mysticall way he hath, though he was not a Magistrate, nor an husband in a temporall way, yet in a mysti all way he is both Lord and husband to the Church.

Lastly, Those graces which suppose sinne as repentance doth, yet our Saviour hath left us an example of those graces, which if wee obtaine they will certainly produce repentance in us, and enable to carry our selves in all duties and in all our relations as becometh Christians, so that as one that should teach us to write, and set us exact Copies, wee should not quarrell with him and say, that he hath been a defective Schoole-Master, because that some of those words that afterwards wee have occasion to write, were never in those Copies that he set us; sufficient it is for him to vindicate himselfe and say, that I have taught you all those Letters, and all those severall joynings, which will spell and make up that word that you are to write whatsoever it be; so Christ hath left us an example of those graces, which are able to spell and make up any duty, or grace wee stand in need of, there are the ingredients, of which all compositions may be made up, if wee follow Christ in our love to God, and our hatred to sinne, our godly sorrow for sinne will necessarily follow, and be made up of these two ingredients, though Christ for his part had never any occasion to use such a composition for himselfe, having never need of that Physicke, and so I come, the objection being removed, to the prosecuting of the point, to shew how wee should be perfect as our Father which is in heaven is perfect.

First, In respect of the kinds of perfections, they must be spirituall and divine: carnall, corporall, or civill or morall perfections are too low for a Christian to looke at, especially to make it his businesse, or the marke he shoots at: morall vertues were the highest perfections of the Heathens, but alas morall vertues transforme us not, they change not our natures,
but onely gild our rottennesse; though one be never so good a natured man, as they call it, if one has not the divine nature, one is but a tame Devill, for one is his childe; if ones nature be not sanctified, and our person justified, and so become the childe of God by regeneration and adoption, and the most excellentest act that is meerely morally vertuous is finne, and cannot please God: let me give a Simile to make this evident; A great Emperour commands his Empresse to come to him, as Ahasuerus did Queene Vasthi; his commands not prevailing, he entreats her, after that sends his Letters full of love and importunity, sends Embassadors after Embassadors, and least those should fayle, sends her many gifts very rich and magnificent, and thus he continues weeke, moneth, yeare after yeare, yet shee utterly refuses, but after her rejecting and slighting all these wayes of love from the Emperour her husband, there comes a base slave, from whose company her husband had especially forewarn'd her, because shee had formerly committed folly with him, and dishonoured both her selfe and the Emperour; this adulterer and traytor speaks but halfe a word to her to goe, and shee presently without delay and with joy goes, when shee perceives it would please the slave: What doe you thinke now, doe you thinke the Emperour will be pleased with her comming upon those termes? this is the case of all men that are no more then morally vertuous, God perswades us to be just, and to defraud no man, he entreats us, sends the Embassadors the Ministers unto us, giveth us mercy upon mercy, sends us his Word, his Epistles from Heaven, line upon line to perswade us to doe justice, or to be temperate, not we, for his sake we will doe nothing: the world comes, the world which is a slave to Satan, for he is a Prince and Ruler of the darknesse of this world, the world with which wee have committed so often spirituall whoredome, and against which God hath so often and seriously forewarned us, now onely upon a supposition that we should please the world if we are just or temperate; we will be intemperately temperate, if I may so say, even to macerate our bodies with fasting, for a good looke of the world, wee doe indeed in being temperate or just, doe that which God commands, but farre are wee from pleasing him, considering the grounds from which we doe it, for can he be pleased that we should doe more for a good looke of the world, then we would for all the wayes of love that he tooke with us, nay indeed never to doe any one action for his sake, nay but before his face at the same time when we refuse all his entreaties, &c. to doe it at the first word of the world, therefore morall vertues, considering the ground upon which they were done are sinnes before God, therefore let us learne not to be vertuous as Philosophers were vertuous, but holy as God is holy.

Secondly, The perfections of God are infinite, so must ours as farre as it is possible for creatures to attaine, our desires of holinesse must be without limits, we must not set bounds to our holinesse, saying, hitherto shalt thou goe and no further, but we must alwayes hunger and thirst after righteousnesse.

Thirdly, God hath all perfections, or rather is all perfections: so we must adde to our faith vertue, to vertue knowledge, to knowledge temperance, &c. We must receive from Christ grace for grace, as a childe receives from the father limbe from limbe, part for part, the same parts that the fathers body hath, the childs hath also, the same for number, figure and position, though neither for strength, nor bignesse: and as God is the act of all possible absolute perfections, either in degree or in kinde, so wee should endeavour to have those perfections that a creature of that kinde is capable of.

Fourthly, As the perfections of God are both inseparable from God and from themselves, so should ours be also; our wisedome must be holy, our holinesse innocent, our wisedome zealous, and our zeale wise; for we must not conceive that some of Gods actions are holy, others wise, but all are all, his wisdome is holy, just, and good; his justice, holy, good and wise, and every attribute is as inseparably united to all the rest of his attributes, as any of them are to his Essence: as if there were an hundred Sunnes shining at once in the Firmament, one could not say that one of these Sunnes shined in this part of the ayre, and another in that, but the light of every one of them would be in every point of the ayre; nor could you possibly take away the light of one of the Sunnes, and leave the rest, unlesse you could take away the Sunne it selfe: so it is in Gods perfection, but thy glorious Name is exalted above all knowledge, above all blessing, and above all praise.

Many men will be zealous, but without knowledge; others will be wise, but without zeale, and so their wisedomes come to be no better then carnall, sensuall, and devillish: the former zeale was that zeale of the Jewes, Rom. 10.2. The other wisedome was the wisedome of Pilate; both of them crucified Christ.

Lastly, For I doe not intend to be large in these parallels, but make hast to presse the great point of Christian perfection; wee must be perfect as our Father which is in heaven is perfect, notwithstanding all hinderances or provocations to the contrary; though God by his wisedome governes and orders all things, not a spire of grasse, or blade of wheat growes but by him, 1 Cor. 15.38. Not a sparrow falls on the ground, nor an haire from our head, but by his providence, not a Lilly is cloathed in the feild, nor a fowle in the ayre is fed but by him, yet notwithstanding such an innumerable number of creatures, are both in respect of their essence and operations, nay even in respect of the smallest circumstances of either, are acted, governed, and ordered continually by his providence; yet he doth no lesse know, love, and enjoy himselfe, then he did from all eternity, before there was any creature for his providence to watch over: so should wee doe, wee should not have our thoughts lesse sixed on God, or our love lesse servent; our communion with God should be neither remitted or intermitted by the imployments in the world; Mothers that have their little Children to looke to, should be like the Angells which all wayes behold the face of our Father which is in Heaven, Mat. 18.11.
But I come (as I promised) to the great businesse of this Treatise, viz. The pressing of Christian perfection, which is almost forgotten, and nothing left of it but the forme of godlinesse; and I shall referre the whole Discourse to these three heads.
First, Severall Considerations.
Secondly, Severall Cautions.
Thirdly, Severall Advises.
Considerations.

1. Consi. Let us consider what the word of God speaks in this matter, 1 Cor. 10.31. Whether yee eate or drinke, or whatsoever yee doe, doe all to the glory of God: doe wee live up to the meaning of these words? let us consider a little of it, and see the meaning of the words.

First, Wee are to glorifie God in all our actions, that is, wee ought in the secret of our hearts to admire and adore him, to have high thoughts of him, and sweet thoughts of him, and to expresse it fully, wee ought to honour him as God, Rom. 1. Which he blames the Gentiles for nor doing, That knowing him as God, did not honour him as God: to honour him but as wee would honour the holiest man in the world, nay the highest Angel in Heaven is nothing, and as great derogation to his glory, as to give his glory to them; for to give the honour due unto God to a creature, and to give that is due unto a creature unto God, are equally vitious: but let us deale freely and openly with our owne soules, doe wee doe so much as that which if we did no more wee were guilty of that great sinne of the Heathens, which the Apostle in the forenamed place doth condemne, doe we honour God as much as we doe honour an Angel, or an holy man? let us but aske our owne consciences, and they will tell us. Would wee doe that in the presence of either of them as wee doe in the presence of God; nay of a childe that is come to that understanding to distinguish between good and evill.

Secondly, By these words wee are enjoyned that our words, actions, gestures, and all our carriages should be such, as may be suitable and fit to raise up those high thoughts of God in others as wee our selves have; for instance; in prayer, we ought not onely our selves to admire and adore our good and glorious God, but so to lift him up and hold forth his excellencies by our very expressions, pronunciations and gestures, that they may be such as may be suitable to our inward admirings of him: but fit to beget the same thoughts in all that heare us; our loves should be like a slame that takes hold of all that comes neere it.

Thirdly, Wee should, as much as in us lies, doe all our actions, and speake all our words with an actuall intention by them to edifie others, and to cause them to glorifie the Lord. Now how farre wee come short of this, wee may even be confounded with shame to speake of it. The second place that sets downe Christian perfection, Phil. 3.20. Wee should have our conversation in Heaven; wee should thinke with our selves how we should live when we come thither, or how those live that are there, or one would live that should come from thence to live on earth againe, how
feelingly would they speake of God? how fervently would they praise him? how would their songs of praise be all flames of love? how are they continually taken up with thoughts of admiration of the excellencies of God, of the love of God; let us not dally with our selves or God, but consider with our selves whether we live in any measure sutable to such a life. But to proceed, let us consider another place, Ephe. 3.19. To say of such an one, that he is a godly man, the holy Spirit of God is in him, that he is full of the Holy Ghost, that he is filled with all the fulnesse of God; if one went upon such relations and expressions to see him of whom they were spoken, doubtlesse one should come with great expectations to meet with one that was wholly taken up with thoughts of God, and if one spake any thing to him of God, doubtlesse one would expect that he should speake wonderfull things of God, with so much admiration, such zeale, such love, with such feelings, that his very word would be able to enflame our hearts with love of God; but if when one came to see such an one, he should entertaine one with vaine and idle jests, with discourses of the world, and spend the whole day generally in recreations, and sometimes when he hath nothing else to doe goe and spend halfe an houre in reading, or in praying, and when he comes from those duties (Iron will be red hot if it be put into the fire for any time) speake as savourly and with as much delight of the vanities of the world, as if he had spent his time not in prayer, but in admiring and gazing upon the beauty of the creature, and if one should speake to him something of God, he should answer one overly, would yee not thinke in your own soules, is this that holy man you spoke of? is he that man that was full of God? But to proceed a little further, 2 Cor. 3.18. the Apostle sayes of himselfe, and of Christians in his dayes, that they were transformed into the image of God; that is, lived the life of God, such a life as Christ lived when he was here on earth; nay, the grace of God in them was in such an high degree, that it might be rather called glory then grace; they lived as if they were of the Church triumphant, in respect of holinesse, though of the Church militant, in respect of afflictions; their grace was of such an high degree, that it was more like glory, as was said before, then grace, yet they did not content themselves with that neither, but made a progresse from glory to glory: Deare Brethren, are our Saviours words but winde, and can wee imagine that the lives of those that take upon them the names of Christians, are any whit sutable to these expressions: many times have I thought of that saying of Erasmus, That since men could not bring the world to Christianity, they have brought Christianity to the world, and those expressions and precepts, that have been too strict to give us liberty to follow the vanities of the world, wee have found out value distinctions and expositions of the places, to make them signifie no more then wee doe, and to quiet our consciences, that they being deceived and laid asleepe, we might not be troubled with their clamours. Our Saviour says, That for every idle word wee must give an account at the last day, Mat. 12.36. The words are so plaine that it will aske one a great deale of labour to sinde out such an exposition
as might not be a continuall accuser of us in all companies, in all discourses, our Saviours example is the best exposition of this precept; we doe not reade in all the Scripture, one word that he spake, but was some way or other to edification, and yet how loose are wee in our discourses? as if there were no such place of Scripture in the whole Bible as these words; surely our time would be better spent in praying to God for strength against our corruptions, then in studying to finde out excuses and intricate expositions of plaine places to justifie them. But you will say, that it is true, these are excellent things, if one could live so, it were a blessed life; but alas, who can doe it?

I answer; First, If thou sayst thou canst not live thus, I aske thee how dost thou know? didst thou ever try what might be done in this case? didst thou ever make it thy businesse? it may be thou hast had some perfunctory and carelesse desires, some cold prayers and faint endeavours, but didst thou ever set thy selfe to it? didst thou ever spend as much time, so many thoughts, with as much earnestnesse, to get acquaintance with God; as men in the world doe in their trades, to get a little thicke clay: didst thou ever pray with halfe that earnestnesse for grace, as ambitious men doe sue for places and preferments, or a condemned man for a pardon? Didst thou ever seriously, and from the very bottom of thy heart and soule say; well, by the blessing of God I will not speake an idle word, nor imploy my selfe in things that profit not: hast thou said with David? I have sworne and I will performe thy righteous Judgements, Psal. 119.106. or as in the 20. or with the Apostle; I fight not as one beating the ayre, but I presse thorough towards the marke, and forget the things that are behinde, &c. So that if thou shalt say, that one cannot live thus, I say againe there is no question, thou canst not live holily, doing no more then thou doest; neither the word of God, nor any one that knowes the wayes of God, ever said or thought that thou couldest upon these termes doe any thing to purpose in the attainment of holinesse: for our Saviour plainly says; Wee must strive to enter in at the straite gate; and, that many shall seeke to enter in (with such a seeking that comes not to the height of striving) and shall not be able: if thou shouldest bid thy servant lift such a peice of timber, and he should goe with his little singer to lift it, and not being able, should tell thee, that he could not lift it: wouldest thou not thinke that he mocked thee in stead of obeying thee? so when we shall complaine of Religion, that it is too difficult a thing, we cannot attaine it, and yet we will not so much as touch it scarce with one of our singers; may not God justly say, that we doe but mocke him, and unjustly murmur against his commands, complaining of their difficulty, when we never tryed, in using the meanes he hath appointed us, what might be done.

Furthermore, Let us consider how farre many of Gods servants, whose stories are recorded in the sacred Scriptures have gone in this way of perfection; it is said, that Enoch walked with God, and that Noah was perfect in his Generations and walked with God. Can we possibly thinke that these Expressions import no more then that sometimes when they had little or
nothing else to doe, they spent their time in prayer and meditation of divine matters, or that they did no more then usually men doe, in the morning spend some small time in prayer; and then take their leave of God all the day, as it were compounding with God for two or three prayers a day; but doth it not much rather import a sweet, constant, and strict communion with God; for doubtlesse Enoch found so much sweetnesse in his walke with God, that he could not be content with that communion that earth could afford him. And of all the Patriarks before the Flood, wee reade of none that lived so few yeares upon earth as Enoch did; and doubtlesse those yeares which he did live were more tedious to him to be so long absent from the full fruition of God, then if he had lived ten times as long, and had not tasted of those joyes, in comparison of which the pleasures of this world are but as the gall of Aspes. What thinke we of Abraham, Moses, David, and Daniel? with how much faith, zeale, meeknesse, holinesse, breathings after God did they live? What high expressions of joy, love, & heavenly desires are there in the Psalmes? What doe we thinke all these holy Examples are set downe in the Scripture to finde us matter of discourse? or that the wisedome of God set downe an Idaea of holinesse, as Plato hath done of a Common wealth, or were they not set downe for our imitation? thousands of expressions almost in the Psalmes we must make strange Hyperboles, say they, was but Davids Rhetoricke, or else wee must needs acknowledge that he was a Gyant in comparison of us in spirituall matters. O what heavenly spirituall frame of heart had he! surely his righteousnesse in respect of Christs was but as filthy rags, but in respect of ours a glorious robe: and now I pray, what reason is there in the world, why we might not live as holily as they, but that we take it for granted, we cannot, and so never strive; 'tis true, to thinke our selves holier then the meanest Saint, is pride, but not to strive to be as holy as the highest Saint is sinne: what meanes had they to attaine holinesse that we have not; they had prayer, meditation, reading, hearing; so have we; if their prayers and meditations were more fervent, and more heavenly, who must we blame, God is not a barren wildernesse unto us, and his grace is as sufficient for them; they had Circumcision, and the Passeover, the breasts of the new Testament are as full of grace as those of the old; nay doubtlesse in respect of meanes they are farre more abundantly glorious in our dayes then in theirs, in respect of knowledge of Jesus Christ, and the mysteries of salvation: may we not say as our Saviour does, that of all that was borne of Women, there was none like John the Baptist, and yet the least in the times of the Gospell is or may be greater then he: and what enemies or hinderances have we that they had not? was Satan, the flesh, the world, all or either of these not their enemies as much as ours? or had they better weapons or armour to fight against them then we have? wee have the armour of God, they could have no better: if you shall say, you had a great family to provide for, weighty affaires and imployments lay upon you, and these are great hinderances: in all these they exceeded thee, and yet they were
no hinderances to them in comparison of that, generally they are to us; Abraham drew three hundred out of his family to deliver Lot, besides what men, women, and children were left behinde. Job had also a great family, he was a Judge, and a Prince, and yet notwithstanding in all the whole world there was none like unto him. So David had a whole Kingdome to looke to, besides continuall warres, and yet how often did he pray, every day; how frequent was he in meditation? without all question did we make it our businesse to entreat the Lord for strength and grace to serve him, were we frequent and servent enough in such desires, did wee seeke for wisedome as for silver, and search for understanding as for hid treasures, wee might doe wonders in Religion, in comparison of what we doe. And if you shall say, that all these you speake of are Prophets. I answer; what then? for the gifts of Prophecy were not gifts of sanctification, but of edification, they might have been as holy, and not have been Prophets, and they might have Prophesied, and yet be workers of iniquity. But to returne to what we spake, surely if men had saith, and that wrought by love as it should doe; if wee were as watchfull over our wayes as we might be, if we were not wanting to our selves, and to God, (for he is not wanting unto us) we might live many dayes, without doing ot speaking any thing that materially is a sinne: I doe assuredly know, that no one thought, word, or action, but in some respect or other is sinfull, either the ground is not spirituall, or not so spirituall, the end is not heavenly, or not so heavenly, we doe not purely aime at the glory of God, nor purely doe it out of obedience to God, and in the name of Christ, &c. as we should; therefore I doe not say, we can live one minute without sinning against God, but one may live many houres and dayes without doing such actions which materially and in their own nature are sinnes: as now for those which are accounted grosse sinnes in the world, and are so, as adultery, murder, theft, blasphemy, swearing; it may be some of Gods people live their whole life without actually committing any one of them. What is meant by that that is said of Zachary and Elizabeth, that they lived blamelesse, Luk. 1.6. And what is meant by that of St Paul, 1 Cor. 4.4. That he knew nothing by himselfe: well, certainly those that love not to keepe a strict communion with God, and love not the truth, may finde excuses enough to bolster themselves up in their carelesse walke; nay, let them take heed, least they so provoke the Lord, that he sends them strong delusions to beleive lies. It may be, they will plead the infirmities and falls of the Saints, Noahs drunkennesse, Davids adultery, Peters deniall, and so encourage themselves in their own wickednesse; surely these failings of the Saints are set downe as sands and rocks to avoyd, not as our Compasse whereby we should steere our course: 'tis true, if after prayers and strivings against those sinnes, through the strength of our corruptions we fall into some sinne, we may take comfort from the infirmity and faylings of the Saints: but before our fall, what use have we of such faylings, but onely rocks, as I have said, comforts they may be after but not encouragements before, otherwise our spots are not the spots of Gods people.

2. Consi. The second Consideration is, that no art, science, or trade whatsoever, is attained without some yeares being prentice or studying of it; and can we imagine that we can attaine to any measure of perfection in Religion, without spending either time or thoughts about it, but making it a thing meerely by the by. The unreasonablenesse of this conceit appeares the more, if we consider that we have no such impediments to hinder us from the attainment of excellencies in trades, arts, and sciences; nay those things that are hinderances in the attainment of holinesse, doe further us in the attainment of such kinde of excellencies; to be an excellent workman in any trade, or to be an excellent Physitian, neither the world, nor our corruptions, nor Satan, are against it, the world generally doth promise and employ such persons; when they have an occasion to use any one of any trade or calling, they use the skilfullest, and so they are an encouragement to them: and for our corruptions, they doe not hinder, but rather further; for we pride our selves generally in such kinde of excellencies; and if the world, nor the flesh be not, certainly Satan is not against them neither, but against holinesse they are all enemies. Now if we should see a man rowing, having both winde and tide with him, and should row with all his might, and yet with much adoe come to such a place by night, and the next day being to row back againe against winde and tide, should take no paines at all, but lie sleeping in the Boat, as if the streame that was against him, should carry him backe of it selfe: when men shall spend so much paines, so many thoughts to get an estate; and in things concerning God and eternity, should carry themselves as if they were either not worth having, or as if holinesse like weeds should grow of it selfe.

3. Consi. The third Consideration is, that there is no paine nor trouble in its selfe in Religion, nor no true pleasure nor profit in sinne, or what pleasure or paine soever there is in them, it is so short and so small, that it deserves not the name of either, doe but truly and seriously consider, what paine or trouble is there in spending an houre, in reading, meditating, or praying, I speake to the most disadvantage; for indeed one should rather say, what wonderfull delight there is in a strict and constant communion with God in such duties: but let it be supposed it be troublesome, the trouble is nothing, but the comfort and the benefit is exceeding great; when thou hast spent a day in humbling thy soule before God, I pray, next day is it any paine or trouble to you? in respect of them, it is as the way of a Serpent upon a stone, there is nothing of the trouble that did accompany, those holy duties doth remaine when they are ended, but the comfort and profit of them thou mayest meet withall twenty yeares hence: and so for sinne, the pleasure of it is momentany, but the guilt and sting of it is eternall; the poore empty pleasures of sinne, what are they while they doe continue? but sure I am, they are bitternesse at the last, to have a guilty conscience, and a wounded spirit, but one houre in any extremity, as poore soules in dissertion or despaire have, hath so much horror in it, that doubtlesse whosoever hath had any experience in
such things, would not endure them for all the pleasures in the world for Methusalems age: but alas we looke not a farre off, consider neither the end of holinesse, nor of sinne; nay to speake the truth, we consider not the essentiall excellency of the one, nor filthinesse of the other.

4. Consi. Fourthly, Consider that there is not the least sinne, nor the least holy thought that shall vanish into ayre or into nothing; for if God shall call us to account for every idle thought or word, shall not every holy thought and word through his mercy tend to our good also? if the wicked doe treasure up wrath against the day of wrath, as a man that should cast in every day many peices of silver and gold into a roome for twenty yeares together, or more, when he should come to looke in that roome at the twenty yeares end, he would finde many a peice wh • ch he had forgotten; so it is with one that treasures up since, when the booke of conscience shall be opened at the last day, and the baggs wherein God sealed up his sinnes, as Job speakes, how many sinnes will he meet withall that he never thought of untill that day? not one of them shall be lost that ever he cast in: so surely it will be with thee that treasurest up prayers and holy thoughts; God doth as safely seale up them as he doth the sinnes of the wicked: there is a booke of remembrance writ of all thy good words, and there is a bottle to bottle up all thy teares: now how easie is it for thee to cast into this treasury a thousand holy thoughts a day, to what a numberlesse number would they arise to in few yeares; and by these not any businesse is hindred; thou mayst ride, thou mayst eate and drinke, thou mayst sell and buy, thou mayst walke for all them: now if every holy thought doth adde something to thy grace here, and to thy glory hereafter, and since they doe not hinder, but sweeten and sanctifie all imployments, why doest thou not treasure up these against the day of the Lord.

5. Consi. F • ftly, Consider seriously the excellencies of the Scriptures, for we are not sensible enough of their worth, no • doe wee firmely and seelingly enough believe that they are the word of God: Suppose that by some infallible arguments it might be demonst • ated that there were a Prophet now in England, with what extraordinary care and observation would you observe his words that he spake in the name of the Lord: If when thou wert powring out thy soule before God, humbly begging of him that he would discover • o thee more the things that belong to thy peace, and thou shouldest have an Angel from Heaven coming unto thee, as one did to Cornelius, or that our Saviour should himselfe speake to thee from Heaven, as he did to Paul, when thou shalt say as he did; Lord, what wouldst thou have me to doe? With what reverence and attention wouldest thou observe, and what obedience to a title wouldest thou give to such Messages? Wouldest not thou marke every word, and every syllable? and wouldest not vary from them one jott. Well, thou shouldest give no lesse reverence nor obedience unto the Word of God, then unto them. If thy friend speakes to thee, or writes to thee, so thou art sure that it is his hand, they are both of equall authority with thee; and why
should not the word of God immediately spoken from heaven, or written be so too, of equall authority with thee? to have an Angel from heaven to tell thee what thou shouldest doe, is a stronger temptation to pride, but there is no more of reality in it to move thee to obedience, then there is in the written word; nay, may I not say lesse, for the Word of God is the rule by which we must judge their Messages; and not their Messages the rule by which we must judge the Word of God; for if an Angel from Heaven should preach another doctrine, let him be accursed. Now there is no reason, thou beleeving the Bible to be the Word of God, which we all professe, but thou shouldest with as much care endeavour to understand and practile what therein is written: if we will doe but as Luther did that he might understand, Rom. 3.25, 26. fast and pray when we finde any place of Scripture too d • fficult to be understood, or when we found our corruptions so strong that we obeyed not: when it is understood, if we sought the Lord by prayer and fasting, a duty generally neglected, and by some condemned, though by the Apostles commended and practised; surely wee should both understand more of the minde of God, and live more sutable to what we know.

6. Consi. S • x • ly, Consider that howsoever we esteeme it matters not, without Question the enjoyment of God is infinite happinesse: for doe but truly and really consider, wherein doth the happ • nesse of Angells consist; doth it not consist in the vision, fruition, and union with God? is not God their all, and shall he not be ours when we come thither? how comes it to passe, that it is not so now? nay it is so, but how comes it to passe, that it is not so to us? either the Angells are deceived in making of it their happinesse, or we must be deceived in not making of it ours; we cannot have the face to say, that if the Angells knew what pleasure there were in eating and drinking, and other vaine and wicked pleasures of the world, they would never spend their eternity in singing the praises, in beholding the face, and admiting the excellency of God; yet though we are ashamed to say thus, yet by our lives we generally hold forth this blasphemy, and proclaime it to the whole world; nay, let me raise this one step higher, the blessednesse of God wherein doth it consist, the creature is not his happinesse but himselfe, and if God be enough for himselfe, shall he not be enough for thee? oh dust and ashes his enjoyment of himselfe, is his happinesse, how comes it to passe that it is not thine? God doth command, invite thee, entreate thee to enjoy him; nay indeed what is it that God requires of thee, but this, even to admire, love, and enjoy him in the secret of thy soule, thou wilt not, thou preferrest every trifle before him; thou wilt goe and see a carnall friend for carnall ends, rather then spend thy time in the enjoyment of him, who is the praise, and above the praise of men, and Angells to all eternity; pray to him who onely can discover his love and excellencies to thee, that he would make thee taste of this hidden Manna; that he would draw away the vaile from before thine eyes, that thou mayst be no longer ignorant of this truth; that he would purge out those corruptions out of thy heart, that thou mayst relish and experiment the sweetnesse of it.

7. Consi. Seaventhly, Consider that we have three enemies, the world, the flesh, and the Devill; Consider this, I say, fully and feelingly, for few there are that live so much as a tittle of this truth; or who lives as if the world was his implacable enemy? for do we not generally into all our actions put something of that poysonous ingredience, viz. a desire to please men, and to get their good word and will; we ought not to scandalize any one as much as in us lyes; we ought to be all things to all men; but it is that we may gaine them to God, not to our selves: if this truth was ingraven in our hearts, that it is as possible to goe to heaven and please the Devill, as goe to heaven and please the world. I say, if we were fully perswaded in our hearts of that truth, we would neither wonder the world hates us, nor endeavour that it should love us: we should not endeavour nor cast away our paines to doe that which is absolutely impossible; so then if we resolve to be Christians, we must neither feare nor care what the world can say of, or doe unto us. And we should in all our actions of Religion, not so much as once bring it into our consideration, to thinke what men will say or doe unto me, if I doe so, or so, except it be by their dislike to helpe our selves to know what is right; for though it is not an absolute rule, yet it is a generall rule, that such a thing is right, because men generally speake against it; certainly, our desires and endeavours to please men, is one of the greatest snares in the world; for generally we live so that we enslave our selves, and loose not onely our Christian, but our naturall liberty for men; but indeed if it was no more but our outward liberty, it was nothing, but we wound our consciences, and offend our God, which is worth more then a thousand Heavens.
Cautions.
1. Caut. First, Take heed of the perfunctory performance of holy duties; for many mischiefes come by them.

First, They puffe up, not edifie; if thou powrest out thy soule before God in prayer, feelingly, spiritually, and faithfully, thou never departest without some spirituall profit; but if thou dost it carnally and formally, thy prayers are but winde, and they puffe thee up, for thy carnall heart would plead these carnall performances to thy conscience, and make thee believe because thou hast many peices of this counterfeit coine, that thou art rich and wantest nothing, though thou art poore and blinde and naked and miserable; for thy duties have not the right stamp, having neither the image nor superscription of God upon them, being neither performed for the glory of God, nor by the Spirit of God, nor in the name of Christ: and between carnall and spirituall duties, this is the difference, that wee usually pride our selves in the one, and are humbled by the other.

Secondly, Which followes upon the former, we shall grow weary in time of performing carnall duties, for needs must we be weary of these things from which we get no profit nor strength: when duties are dry breasts unto us, it is no marvell if we are weary of drawing them; by spirituall duties we get strength; and such prayers doe enable us to pray more; but carnall prayers tire us.

Thirdly, Consider the same time is spent in the one as in the other, whether thou hearest or prayest, with zeale and attention, or without it, takes up the same time in the Publique Congregation, though not the same profit.

Fourthly, Consider that you spoyle both, by mixing the thoughts of worldly businesse with spirituall duties; for thy outward performance of the duty keeps thy thoughts of businesse from coming to maturity, & the thoughts of worldly things keepe thy prayers from doing thee any good, so that they spoile one another; I meane of those wandring thoughts that we let lie in our duties, for those that are resisted and removed and mourned for, doe somewhat hinder but not putrifie the duty; for as the Wise man saith; That dead flyes cause the ointment of the Apothecary to send forth a stinking savour; if one takes out a fly as soone as it is come into it, so much of the ointment that stickes about the fly is lost, but the rest remaines sweet and pure, as it was before: so wandring thoughts spoyle something of our prayer, though they be resisted and removed, they make a little hole in our prayer by taking up that time which should have been fild up with better thoughts; but if they continue, they eate up the fat of those sacrifices, and make the sweet odours of our prayers noisome. But to conclude this Caution, if we were but in any measure sensible of the Majesty of him to whom, and the necessitie of those things for which we pray (to instance in that duty) for they are our life and of the necessity of having them from God, we need no other Motives to deterre us from perfunctory performances.

2. Caut. Secondly, Take heed of worldly company, for whosoever delights in that, will finde that he never comes out of it but worse then he comes into it; for when one goes into such company among whom there is nothing spoken of God, of Christ, or of the Spirit, of the Word of God, and of spirituall experiences, where there is no spirituall duty performed; except one be exceeding carefull to sequester ones minde from their discourses, and keepe a strict communion with God in the secrets of our hearts, our graces if they were strong would grow weake, and our corruptions though they were weake would grow strong, and that spirituall advantage which you have got by many prayers you will finde will be lost in a little time spent in such company, except their discourses be as dry breasts unto you, and as Messech and Kedar were unto David, they must either be a griefe or sinne unto them, except in some cases, as in case of businesse, thy particular calling, or charity, if thou comest as a Physitian, either of their bodies or of their soules, then thou not onely mayst but oughtest to come unto them; in such cases, our Saviour did frequently eat with Publicans and finners, not out of any love he had to their worldly conversation, but to their conversion: and this must be taken as a rule, he that knowes not how to be alone, knowes not how to be in company with profit.

3. Caut. Thirdly, Take heed of idlenesse; for as the Wise man says; Seest thou one wise in his own eyes, there is more hope of a foole then of him: for to make such a man wise, there are two things to be done.

First, You must bring him to that, that he may know himselfe to be ignorant, and then you must teach him wisedome, whereas he that is ignorant, and knowes himselfe to be so, needs onely the last; so he that is in any honest employmēt, Satan hath two works to do to make him sin.

First, He must get h • m to leave off what he is doing, and then perswade him to the evill that he tempts him to: as a bowle that is running must be first stopped before it can be made to run the contrary way; whereas the bowle that lyes still may without stopping be cast what way one pleases: a bird that is flying one can hardly take any aime at, as one may at that which sits still: so Satan cannot levell his temptations so at a busie as at an idle man: but I shall not prosecure this common place of idlenesse, but my maine designe is to give you caution against spirituall idlenesse, for that which is not taken notice enough of, that is not avoyded nor mourned for enough is that we thinke that we are not idle, if we are busied in worldly employments, if we are selling of wares in our shops, or riding of a journey, or busied in some such employment of our particular calling. The man thresheth and plowes all day and thinkes that he is free from idlenesse; but we should know that if our thoughts are not employed upon spirituall things when they may, it is the worst idlenesse of all, and very few worldly businesses there are that stand in need of the continuall intention of our thoughts upon their, for it is rather our love of the world that f • xeth our thoughts upon worldly matters while we are employd about them, then because they might not be done as well without halfe that intention of minde; doubtlesse there are many disseminata vacua in all employments of the world, which might and ought to be filled up with spirituall thoughts; and as it is with Bees though they gather honey from a flower, they leave it as fragrant and as fresh as they sound it; so we gathering and mixing spirituall thoughts with and from our worldly businesse, we hinder it not at all; for as a vessell that is full of sand will hold almost as much water as if there were no sand in it; so when we are full of employments, we may hold a thousand holy thoughts; and as a ship can hardly be so fild with chests or other lading, but there will be so many corners unfild up, wherein Diamonds of such great value might be put in, that they would be more worth then all the lading of the Ship; so those thoughts of God and spirituall things which we might have in the midst of our other employments, as may be of farre greater value then they.

Fourthly, Take heed of perfunctory and carelesse resisting of temprations, but what thou dost in that particular as in spirituall things doe it with all thy might, for to thinke and weakly to resolve against sinne, will not hinder but aggravate thine offence, and it is one of Sarans policies to let one alone to thinke of severall Morives against any sinne, when he sees that he hath one fast enough; for he knowes that the more Motives we sinne against, the more we are hardened, and God is provoked: and as it is with a Towne that is besieged, they will willingly let so many of their enemies in, as they know they are able to master; so Satan when he sees
that the Motives and resolutions that enter into the soule are too weake, he willingly suffers them to enter, for perfunctory performances of duties and resisting of temptations, are equally dangerous, if the latter be not the worst; by the former we get no spirituall good, and by the latter we overcome no spirituall evill.

5. Caut. Take heed of making others sinne, either by scandall, or being a temptation to them by example or provocation, it is a good way when one hath to deale with a passionate man, not onely to prepare our selves for the Combate by prayer and resolutions and keeping a strong guard upon our hearts, that we may not be overcome with passion, howsoever he shall use us, either in word or in deed; but to take speciall care and to use all means to keepe him from passion; for there is a wretched joy that our hearts are subject to take in the sins of others, thinking them to be a foile to our innocency, to have others very passionate when we are very meeke; there is a secret delight that the heart is prone to take, but it proceeds from a desperate pride in us, who desire to have our excellencies made manifest, though with the dishonour of God and damnation of our brothers; but there is a great deale of hell in it, and charity rejoyceth not in ill. 1 Cor. 13.

6 Caut. Take heed of studying high speculative points whatsoever, for when our thoughts are exceedingly intent in finding our truths, all the fire is in the top of the chimney, and none is left upon the hearth, generally high speculations leave the heart cold without devotion, for generally there is a great deale of curiosity and pride in such studies, for commonly we desire to be accounted knowing men, in searching into whys and hows of Gods works and truths; as why God made the tice of knowledge of good and evill, and how there can be three persons, and but one God, therefore in all reading joyne prayer, whether it be in the reading of humane or divine things, and take speciall care that the love of God goe not out nor grow cold in you. That which I have heard of one, is a good practice, that whatsoever booke he was reading, every leafe that, he turned over he would looke what was become of his heart, and of God, and would not begin till he had sent up some prayers to the Lord for direction.
Advises.
1. Adv. First, Concerning writing, many wayes thou art to employ that for thy advantage.
First, Write downe all those spirituall passages out of Sermons, books, discourses, wherein thou hast sound most relish and spirituall profit.

Secondly, Keepe a Register of all the mercies that God hath bestowed upon thee, whether it be temporall or spirituall, but especially thy spirituall experiences, and his manifestations of his love, if ever the terrours of the Allmighty was upon thee, the wayes of Gods providence in supporting thee, and how, and when, and in what manner he delivered thee.
And so for the discoveries of his love, and concerning the mercies God hath bestowed upon thee, how and whether, and when h answers your prayers; as also all the speciall wayes of Gods providence to other spirituall persons, in temporalls or spiritualls, and when thou findest thy heart dull and cold in love, or weake in saith, these experiences of Gods goodnesse to thy selfe and others, will be an excellent means to enflame and strengthen thee.

Lastly, Keepe a Diurnall of thy life in respect of the spirituall passages of every day; set downe whether thou didst awake with God, or whether the world had the first fruits of thy thoughts, and how thou didst performe spirituall duties, whether with relish, fervency, or delights, or otherwise; marke and set downe when thy heart made any default, intermitting its communion with God, and all the severall sinnes that thou canst take notice of, that thou hast committed that day, and what mercies thou hast received, and when there is any mercy that thou prayest for some marke should be set untill thou hast an answer of that prayer from God, and that day the Lord gives thee that answer, make a reference from that day to the day of the praying for that mercy.

2. Adv. Secondly; Choose some spirituall friend one or more, to whom thou mayst wholly unbosome thy selfe in all spirituall matters; but a great deale of caution need to be had in this particular, he need to be one of a thousand that thou choosest; thus thou needest have a great deale of experience of his spirituall wisedome, humility, and experience of the wayes of God, for be he never so learned, though he understand all mysteries & all knowledge, though he hath never such excellent gifts of edification, yet if he be not an experienced Christian, thou wilt little benefit either by his society or counsell, for when he speaks of spirituall and experimentall truths, and the discourses of such truths are the very life of the communion of Saints, I say that his discourses concerning such matters, be he never so learned, if he be not experienced in them will be without life or relish, be will seldome speake of such things, but when he does it, it will be with so much heaviness, that thou mayst clearely perceive that he doth speake but by rote, and of things that he delights not in, and for his advise in spirituall matters it must needs be very imperfect, for thousand cases may happen of which bookes speake nothing; and having no other way to understand them, and direct thee, he will be at a losse, as one that travells by a Map, and hath no other way to guide himselfe, he will meet with many turnings, that put him to a non plus which way to take, whereas he that hath often travelled that way is a farre safer guide; the truth is, we have no knowledge of God, or no saving knowledge of him, but what is by experience: to conclude therefore, if thou wilt choose a spirituall friend, choose such an one as magnifies Christ, and the Spirit of God, and his teachings, and the word of God and inward mortifications above outward, and that is an experienced wise and humble Christian, and thou shalt get a world of good by the converse of such an one, for in doubts his
wisdome and experience will direct thee, in thy distresses he will comfort thee, when thou art spiritually cold, his example and carriage in the performance of holy duties, his discourses of heavenly things, and the flames of his love will set thee on fire.

3. Adv. The third is diurnall examination, every night strictly to examine what thou hast done that day; we reade of God himselfe that every day he looked over his workes: surely God hath no need to examine his workes, but it is writ for our instruction, and doubtlesse the benefit and necessitie of this examination are very great.

First, Wee should finde out our sinnes before they come to be customary, when they are but a day old, and before they have taken root in us, and so they will easily be pull'd up, and by saith, repentance, prayer, and resolutions against them, we shall easily get the victory over them, and through the helpe of God, who makes us more then conquerours; it is very likely by the blessing of God, if David had not neglected the examining of his soule that day when he defiled Bathshebah, he would have discovered that abomination, and he would never have gone so farre as to have added bloud and the rest of his abominations to his uncleanenesse, and he would have watered his couch with his teares, which he had defiled with his adultery.

The second advantage is that we shall never lie in any sin unrepented of, and there be many other inconveniences besides bringing it to a custome that comes by sinne lying, and our soules unrepented of; for it deads our prayers, cooles our love, hardens our heart, makes us that we cannot come to God with that joy, with that freedome of spirit, as when one hath done ones friend an injury, one is loath to see him.

The third advantage is by our dividing this great worke of giving up our account, and making all even betwixt God and our selves, the worke will be very easie, which if we shall not doe it but at our death, or onely yearely, it would be exceeding difficult, and almost impossible: as if some Merchant who had very great trading, should ballast his accounts of debts, receipts of disbursements, &c. but once in seven yeares, it would be an intolerable burden; besides, many things would be forgotten, whereas it being done daily, his accounts are perfected with more ease and fewer defaults.

The fourth advantage is that at thy death thou wilt have a world of comfort by taking this course; for besides that thou art eased of that burthen of having all the accounts of thy life to make up then, thou hast a cleere way to answer Satan, when he shall lay to thy charge any sinnes of thy sormer life; for if he shall accuse thee, and say dost thou not remember, that such a yeare, and such a day, thou didst commit such a sin; thou mayst answer him, and say, it is true that such a day I did commit such a sinne, but then that very night I mourned for it, and went not to bed before I had my pardon sealed with the bloud of Christ to my soule; and when Satan shall not be able to lay to thy charge any debt of which thou
hast not had an acquitance, nor any sin for which thou hast not had a pardon from the Lord, such fiery darts will have no power to wound thee: and this examination thou mayst make thus: Consider all the severall houres of the day, and how thou hast spent them; when thou didst first awake, what didst thou thinke of when thou wert asleepe, and thoughtst not of thy selfe, God thought on thee, and thou were safe under the shadow of his wings; When I awake thou art with me, says David; was not God with David when he was asleepe? yes surely; for his being with him when he was awake, shewed that he was there before; for it is not said, When I awake thou comest to me, but art with me. Well, but what are thy thoughts when thou first waketh? are they of God, or of the world? Thou shalt much discover the temper of thy heart by this, those that are our very familiar acquaintance, we suffer them to come into our chambers before we are up: surely God is a stranger to thee, if thou thinkest not of him, nor seekest him on thy bed; then as the Apostle says, If the first fruits are holy, the whole lumpe is holy: so generally as thy first thoughts are, such art thou all the day after: in the morning thou sayst, it will be foule weather, says our Saviour, for the skie is red and lowring; so we may say of the day in respect of spirituall matters; if thy morning thoughts be red and lowring, it will be foule weather in thy soule that day: and when thou readest over thy diary thou shalt finde that those dayes when thou shalt finde that thy waking and morning thoughts were full of God, that all the duties of that day, whether of thy generall or particular calling, were of God also. Well, what didst thou thinke of afterwards, didst thou keepe thy thoughts close to God, untill thy morning exercise? didst thou dresse thy soule as thou didst dresse thy body? Well, after that what didst thou d • e such an houre and such an houre, &c.
