Or to helpe thee in this duty something more, examine at night thy workes, words, thoughts, what they were every houre of the day; for thy works, consider what thy religious workes, the works of thy particular calling, and thy recreations were; for thy prayers, hast thou not omitted thy seven times a day, if thou hast attained with David to that number? or how often soever thy set times are, hast thou not omitted them? for I dare not discourage any one in observing set times as if that could not be don lawfully. Well, how hast thou prayed, hast thou performed that duty as a taske, or as a means? hast thou bound up thy devotion to such a number of times of going to God? or hast thou given God those prayers as a Composition? or as the rent of the day, that thou mayst doe with the rest and spend the rest in vanity as thou pleasest, or didst thou not much rather performe that duty of prayer as an act of communion with God for the present, and as an helpe for communion with God for the future? Didst thou not by thy prayers intend and desire of the Lord power and strength not to depart from him. What were thy prayers? were they faithfull, fervent, reverend, humble? What returnes of thy prayers hast thou had this day? hast thou endeavoured to obtaine those mercies and graces that thou prayedst for?
thou mockest God to pray for those things thou endeavourest not for; and thou mockest thy selfe to endeavour for those things thou prayest not for; for thy meditations and reading the Word of God, how hast thou performed them? What power have they had upon thy heart this day? hast thou been more faithfull, humble, charitable, &c? What resolutions didst thou make? and hast thou kept them, &c? Concerning thy reading the Scriptures and meditation, most of the things which are spoken concerning prayer, may be applyed to these also: as didst thou meditate and reade as a taske, or as a means? and so of the rest. Concerning the workes of thy particular calling, have they not justled out the workes of thy generall calling? hast thou not unnecessarily omitted thy set times for spirituall duties? or have not thy thoughts been taken up too much with them? hast thou not left off thy communion with God? God may be with thee in thy shop as well as in thy Closet. Againe, if thou art a tradesman, hast thou not tooke advantage of the necessity of the seller, and bought too cheape, and of the ignorance of the buyer, and sold too deare? hast thou not sold thy conscience with thy wares? Concerning thy recreations, have they not been unlawfull recreations in respect of the kinde? hast thou not made a sport of sinne, making that a recreation which should be thy griefe? making that thy delight, which should make a Christian weepe? have not thy recreations been unlawfull in respect of time? have they not been unseasonable? hast thou not used recreations, when thou shouldest have put on sackcloth, not being sensible of the afflictions of Joseph? for have not thy recreations taken up too much time? hast thou not made a vocation of recreation? the best way is by prayer and by frequent communion with God, to attaine to that spirituall frame of soule, that thou mayest goe to God, as David speakes, Psal 43.4. to make God thy exceeding joy; so shall thy great businesse and designe that thou hast in the whole world be turned into a recreation, and thou shalt need no other, but thou shalt be as those that are in heaven, it shall be thy eternall businesse and delight to admire and praise God? What have thy words been, thou must give an account at the last day for every idle word? how many hast thou spoken this day? where, when, and with whom hast thou discoursed, and what hath thy discourse been of? have thy words been to edification? Remember what the Apostle says, that we must avoyde foolish talking and jesting, which is not convenient; hast thou not this day slandered or spoken ill of thy neighbour? if thou hast, besides thy humbling thy selfe before God, and asking pardon of him, make some recompence to thy neighbour, and put up as many prayers to God for him, as thou hast spoken evill words of him? for thy thoughts, what have they been? have not vaine thoughts lodged in thee? the fountaine of all sinne are our thoughts, if thou keepest them close to God, all the rest will follow, thy words and thy conversation will be spirituall also; hast thou not had a thousand thoughts of God this day? if thou hast not, thou hast lost that which is irrevocable; for though thou hast a thousand thoughts of God
next day, thy losse this day is not thereby recovered, for thy having a thousand thoughts of God this day, doth not hinder thee from having a thousand thoughts next day, but rather further thee; the more thoughts thou hast of God, the more thou mayest have; and for thy thoughts of God, what have they been? have they been fervent as well as frequent? have thy thoughts of God been worthy of God, or have not thy thoughts of God been such that thou shou • dest have had of the world, and the thoughts of the world such as thou shouldest have had of God.

4. Adv. The fourth, is Meditation, a duty of so great concernment, so much profit, that nothing but experience can make one know the benefit of it, and the man of the greatest devotion, and of the heavenliest affections, that we reade of in all the Bible, though indeed for matter of revelations, it may be, something more is spoken of others then of him, I meane David was exceedingly versed in Meditation, and doth speake very much of it concerning his own practise, and commending it to others: you know very well that he sets it downe as the onely, or at least the chiefe exercise of the blessed man, to meditate in the Word of God day and night; he delights in the word of God, and therefore meditates in it, and meditates in it, and therefore delights in it: one that walkes in a garden, sees the beauty, and may smell sweetnesse of the flowers growing there, but it is the Bee that gathers honey out of them: to reade and study the Scriptures, hath a great deale of sweetnesse in it, but it is meditating on the Scriptures that brings the sweetest and lastingest benefit; the end of study is knowledge, but the end of meditation is also holy affections and practise. Now that which I advise and direct in this particular is to know how to reade and meditate on the holy Scriptures, to our greatest spirituall comfort and advantage, and there are many Advises to this purpose.

First, Take the Bible, open it, reade it with the same attention, reverence, and resolution to follow it; as if Christ living on the earth, either, by reason of sicknesse, or some other occasion, not being able to goe to him thy selfe, thou should'st send some spirituall friend with thy humble desires to Christ to advise thee what to beleive & doe, and Christ should send a Letter to thee by that friend, how exceedingly wouldest thou p • ize that Letter? how wouldest thou rejoyce and long to reade it? how strictly wouldest thou observe every syllable? goe take the Bible, open it, and doe likewise. Wee doe not reade that ever Christ writ any thing with his owne hand, save that which he wrote upon the ground, John 8. and what that was wee know not; and what might be the reason? might not one, if not the chiefest reason be, least we should Idolize that place of Scripture, and despise the rest in comparison of that; it is not the hand, but the Spirit of Christ that gives authority to Scripture; wee have strange opinions of the bodily presence of Christ, wee thinke had wee lived in his dayes, wee would have gone to him and acknowledged our sinnes, and craved pardon and direction, and scarce doubt but we should have
obtained both, but wee consider not wee have as neere and as certaine a way to obtaine them now as then, nay wee had the same way as they had; for it was their faith that made them whole, and by faith we may be made so too in respect of spirituall diseases; so if an Angel should bring a Message from Heaven to us, how would wee observe and follow it? the Scripture should be of as great power and authoritie with us as that Message, and indeed more; for if it were possible that such a Message should contradict any thing in the Scripture; the Scripture must be beleeved before it: but of this more largely in the fifth Consideration.

Secondly, Reade every Verse in the Bible with this consideration, that the Holy Spirit of God when he inspired the Apostle, Prophet, or other Pen-men of the holy Scriptures to write that place, did particularly intend thy good in it; for wee must not conceive that the Scripture was written for their good onely who lived in those times when those severall Bookes were published, but to all ages, for every particular man that should live in those severall generations. The Scripture it selfe is plaine in this particular; Rom. 15.4. For whatsoever things were written aforetime were written for our learning, that we through patience and comfort of the Scriptures might have hope Deut. 29.29. The secret things belong unto the Lord our God, but these things which are revealed belong unto us, and to our Children for ever, that we may doe all the words of the Law.

Nay wee reade of a particular promise made to a particular person upon a speciall occasion, if any part of Scripture were not to extend to every particular person that should live while the world lasts, one would thinke it should be that, yet even that very promise the Apostle beings, even that as a promise particularly to be applyed to every Christian: compare but these places, Heb. 13.5. Josh. 1.5. The Scripture like a well made Picture lookes upon every one in particular, so directly as if it looked upon none else: wee generally reade the Scriptures as we heare Sermons, without a particular and personall application of them; if a godly Minister should come home to any one of our houses, and take one aside, and tell one privately and feelingly, you professe your selves Christians, but there is little or nothing of Christianity appeares in your lives, you live not as becomes the Gospell of Jesus Christ; it would startle us; wee heare the same in the Pulpit, and we set it passe as a thing not concerning us: if one should come from an house of uncleannesse, and heare a voice from Heaven, saying, Whoremongers and adulterers God will judge, it would strike teriour into that mans heart; he reads the same words in the Scripture, and they are a dead letter to him.

Thirdly, Reade the Scripture to a right end, for which it was written, not for custome, or that you might be able to discourse, and because you are ashamed to be ignorant of those things which you conceive every Christian should know, and having an occasion divers times in company
in such matters, then you would be leath to be able to say nothing; but consider what end the Scripture was writ for, Rom. 15.4. Rev 3, 10. 1 Pet. 2.2. 2 Tim. 3 16. and many other places, let them downe: our knowledge, our affections and our lives are quire out of frame, and thou must goe to the holy Scriptures there to fince out directions to cure these distempers: and in a word, that thou mayst be able to know, admire, love, feare, trust, and serve God more then thou doest; thou should'st never reade any part of the word of God, without a particular intention to advantage thy selfe in these particulars by thy reading.

Fourthly, Thou must humbly and earnestly pray to the Lord to give thee his Spirit to understand what thou readest in his Word; take heed of going with thine owne humane spirit, and in he strength of thy learning, to search out the deepe things of God; goe to the shallows of the workes which wee call the workes of Nature, and thou shalt finde that thou art not able to fadome them; the winde thou hearest the sound thereof, but knowest not whence it comes, nor whither it goes, and how canst thou presume to understand the great mysteries of God which the Angells themselves desire to looke into, without the helpe of the Spirit of God which teacheth wisedome secretly; let thy desires be fervent, for the things written in the Word of God are thy life; defire the Lord to give thee a powerfull, spirituall, and experimentall knowledge, of the truths that thou shalt reade.

Fifthly, Promise the Lord that if he will but reveale to thee his will, thou wilt doe it, and obey him in it, whether it be good or evill; Jer. 42.6. whether it be pleasing or displeasing to thine own will: wee doe not use to tell any one a receipt to cure a disease he is sicke of, if wee know he is resolved not to take it, nor doe thou satisfie thy selfe with a neutrality, to finde thy selfe neither resolved to follow, nor not to follow what thou shalt understand, it is an hard thing when one whom God hath loved so much shall give no other returne of all his goodnesse but this, that he doth not finde his heart to hate and rebell against him: many people doe little better then use the Scripture as a charme, they thinke by reading so many Chapters a day, they shall be cured of all spirituall diseases, had they not as good thinke that by hanging some Chapters or two about their necke, they shall be cured of some corporall disease; if one should have a receipt to cure the gout, and he should reade it over every day twice or thrice, and thinke thereby to be cured, though he never tooke what was prescribed; so it is with him that thinkes the bare reading of the Word of God will doe him any good without being, beleeving, and doing accordingly.

Sixthly, When thou art thus prepared read that place which thou intendest to meditate of, and consider what the true meaning of the place is, to the understanding whereof before thou didst crave the assistance of the Spirit of God, but if the place be knotty and hard to be
understood, passe it by, for such places are not proper places of meditation, but of study; for meditation thou must choose those places of Scripture as are fit for the affectionate, not the speculative part of Divinity, such as may more affect the heart, then busie the braine to understand it, and thou must not be curious to raise nice observations from the words, but take those truths that lie open in the Text.
First, Because those truths that lie hidden in one place of Scripture are obvious in another.
Secondly, Because when the braine is much implyed, the heart lyes dead without affections.

Thirdly, Because that time thou spendest in finding out curious observations may be farre more profitably spent in working thy heart to holy affections and resolutions from some other truth that will presently occurre from the words.
Lastly, It shewes that there is not so great spirituall hunger after righteousnesse as there should be; for hungry men doe not use to stand and picke bones when they have meate enough to eate.

Seaventhly, When thou hast raised any observation from the words, then thou art to put one of these three Questions to thy selfe; Doe I thus? Is it thus with me? and beleeve I thus? One or two, or all of these will belong to every Text, some to all, and all to some, as Luke 19.32. Feare not little flocke, it is your Fathers good will to give you the Kingdome: Doe I thus, that is, for the first branch feare not; doe I feare, then is it thus with me; am I little in my owne eyes, am I one of Christs flocke, am I one of that small number that shall be saved? Lastly, doe I beleeve, this, that God will give the Kingdome of Heaven to such.

Eighthly, If thou doest finde, that thou art, doest, or beleevest as the Word requires, give God the praise, humbly acknowledging that it is not thy doing at all, either that thou art or doest, or beleevest what thou shouldest, and if thou findest that thou pridest thy selfe instead of being thankfull, as if they were from thy selfe, or that by any of them as thine act thou mayest be justified, then doe but thinke in how many other things thou failest, and how even in these very particulars, if thou considerest, either the measure, manner, ground, and end, thou shalt finde them all to be defective, and thy best righteousnesse not onely to be ragred, but filthy too.
Ninthly, If thou findest that either it is not with thee, or that thou doest not, or beleevest not as the Word requires, then,
First, Humble thy selfe before the Lord, and desire pardon and helpe for the future.

Secondly, Seriously consider what is the reason (if it be that thou beleevest not) why thou art not established in that truth, say to thy selfe, O my soule, God can neither be deceived, nor deceive, and that this is his Word that wee now reade and meditate on, is more certaine then any reason that can possibly be brought against it; consider that generally
the howes and whyes of Gods truths and workes are the things that stumble us; as how can there be three persons and yet but one God; and why should God hate Esau and love Jacob? in those cases say to thy selfe, that for the whyes and howes of Gods word and truths, it is curiosity and pride to enquire of them, except God does reveale them, and we ought to mortifie our desire of knowing them: as that of our Saviour takes place in this case; Blessed are they that beleeve and see not.
Thirdly, Thinke with thy selfe if thou canst remember any other place or places that confirmes the truth that thou doubts of.

Fourthly, Know that that which thou art mainely to enquire of, is of the meaning of the Word of God, not of the truth of it; for we are seriously to consider whether such a place holds forth such a point, not (it appearing to be the plaine meaning of the Text) whether it be true or no, if it be a thing that thou doest not which thou should'st doe, or doest which thou should'st not doe; then seriously consider what are the reasons and grounds of this thy disobedience, and thou shalt finde them to be either the pleasure, profit, or honour of the world; and say, alas, O my soule, can we be so deceived as to be put off with vanities, such as by experience wee have knowne to be vanities, and by faith much more? Shall we leave an Heaven of joyes, the God of mercies? shall we leave Christ, who hath so loved us, that he left all, even the bosome of his Father, and emptied himselfe of all his glory, and filled himselfe with our misery? shall we leave all these for these vanities which wee must leave, and will leave us? Consider the impediments that hinder thee from doing thy duty; consider the temptations and occasions of thy sinne; consider the meanes and motives to avoyde it; remove the impediments; avoyde the occasions; use the means; and thinke of the motives to doe that which the Lord commandeth: but thou must neither thinke to finde out these, nor to use the means, or avoyde the occasions, &c. without imploring humbly and earnestly the direction and assistance of the Spirit of God, to assist and direct thee in the premisses; for you must know that you must finde out and use spirituall Motives, or else thy very avoyding of sinne is sinne, when it is done upon carnall grounds or sinfull Motives.
Tenthly, When thou hast finished all thy Meditations:

First, Thou art to entreat the Lord that he would worke all these truths upon thine heart, and fasten them as a naile in a sure place, that his Word may not be a dry breast unto thee, nor thou a barren Wildernesse unto it.
Secondly, Thou art to blesse God for any spirituall frame of heart, that is either wrought or discovered in thee by this exercise.

Lastly, Choose some speciall truth or point (in which thou art either most defective, or wherein thou hast found most relish, or which thou hast most occasion to make use of that day) and keepe it by thee to thinke of, and doe as those that walke in a garden of fragrant flowers, if one may
have leave, generally he takes some along with him to smell to, the rest of the day; doe thou binde up some spirituall truths out of thy Meditation, and doe likewise.

Last Adv. The last great advice, and that which must serve for an Antidote, least all the other Cautions and Advises being observed, they should be turned into poyson to us, is, that wee should often meditate, and never be satisfied in our soules, untill wee come to a cleare Gospel experimentall knowledge of Christ, without which indeed we are not worthy of the name of Christians; for are we not called Christians from that very name? and doubtlesse if we have not a right knowledge of Christ, we shall make up a Christ to our selves of our prayers, and fastings, and almes, and repentance, and woe be to that soule that at the last day shall have nothing to trust to but his graces and duties, which will accuse him instead of pleading his cause: and two things especially wee should endeavour to know of Christ; first, the excellency of the person and mysteries of Christ; Secondly, the love of Christ.
First, For the excellency of his person, though to say he was both God and man, is indeed to include all; yet some few things I shall speake to manifest this point.

First, That all his people doe receive from him grace for grace, Joh. 1.16. Now if we consider the vast emptinesse and spirituall wants of the people of God, we must needs conclude that he must be an Ocean of excellency that must continually supply them.

Secondly, For I shall be very briefe, setting downe rather heads of Meditation, then Sermon-wise, to dilate upon them. Consider the dignity of his sufferings, for they did satisfie the Justice of God, and that could not be satisfied without something of infinite value, and could not any save onely by reason of the dignity of his person.

Thirdly, Consider how he suffered; what did he suffer, though the paines were exceeding great, yet without any abatement at all of his love of and confidence in God; for while he satisfied the Justice of God by his passive obedience, in suffering the penalty of the Law, he also satisfied and fulfilled the righteousnesse of the Law by his active obedience, which was a wonderfull thing that in the midst of all his agony, and all his Fathers anger, while he was laying upon him the punishment of the iniquity of us all, and spared him not, that even them there should be no abatement at all of his confidence in and love of his Father, but that he should love him and trust in him as much as at any other time; for had there been any abatement, and had he not loved God then with all his soule, with all his might, and with all his strength: and the same may be said of his trusting in God, his sufferings could never have satisfied for sinne, but themselves had stood in need of forgivenesse.

Fourthly, Consider that saying of our Saviour, Joh. 14.9. He that hath seene me, hath seene the Father: the speech of Philip is as if he should say; Wee indeed see a great deale of holinesse and wisedome in thy words and
actions, but would we could see the Father; surely there would be a world of holinesse and wisedome in his words and actions, if he would have lived amongst men as thou Lord hast done, surely then it had sufficed. Now our Saviours answer is as if he should say to Philip, If the Father himselfe had taken humane nature, and lived amongst men, he would not have spoke one word more, or otherwise, nor done one action more or otherwise then I have done, he would not, nay could not have spoke or done more wisely then I have done; So he that hath seene me hath seene my Father.

Fifthly, Consider that those who have had the greatest and highest revelations of divine things, have alwayes had the highest esteeme of, and have most magnified Christ. S. Paul rapt into the third heaven, and saw and heard things there, which was neither possible nor lawfull to be uttered, yet no man speakes higher things of Christ then he, he desires to know nothing but Jesus Christ, and him crucified; accounts all other knowledge but drosse and dogs meat; such knowledge as dogs and swine, reprobates may have; nay, one step further, the very Angells in heaven, though they have the beatificall vision, yet notwithstanding they desire to looke into the great mysteries of the Gospel, 1 Pet. 1.12. Therefore never thinke that thou hast attained to any measure of Christian knowledge before thou seest an excellency in Christ, and an height and depth in the mysteries of the Gospel; which if thou shalt not doe, say within thy selfe, it is so evident that nothing is more in the Word of God; that Christ is the end of all the ceremoniall Lawes, and all the Prophesies of the old Testament; that all the Prophets, nay all the Angells give witnesse; and the Apostle cleerely says, that there is no controversie of this matter of the greatnesse of Gospel mysteries, and therefore that I doe not admire them, it certainly proceeds from my ignorance of them; for if it proceeded from knowledge, without doubt the Apostles that had more knowledge then I, and the Angells which had more knowledge then the Apostles, would never have desired to have knowne more of them; and after thou hast wrought this upon thy heart, and art fully convinced of the truth of it, that there is no knowledge, not onely not so profitable, but not so sweet, not so excellent as this, then humbly beseech the Lord that he would shew unto you, teaching thee by his Spirit the deepe things of God, and that he would not onely to informe and enlighten thy understanding in, but to mamour thy will of the beauties of the mysteries of Christ: wee stand doating and gazing upon humane knowledge, which is but like a poore glow worme compared to the Sun of righteousnesse, but alas, poore thing, it hath neither light not heat, compared to the truths of the Gospel: and we must looke upon Christ as the onely author and finisher of our saith, and justifier of our persons; though we doe all that hath been mentioned, yet we must not so much as make our doing or not doings the least ingredient in our justification: and as Solomon speaks concerning our wisedome, so we must doe in the
matter of holinesse; Leane not thine owne wisedome, saith Solomon; not onely not rely upon it, but not leane on it: wee must not partly trust in our owne wisedome, and partly in the wisedome of God, but wee must wholly rely upon his wisedome; so we must not partly rely upon Christs merits, and partly upon our owne, but wholly on Christ: those sinnes which we doe not commit, we are not innocent of, and those holy duties that we doe performe, we are not innocent in, therefore neither can we escape hell, nor attaine heaven by any thing that we doe, or not doe: and the reason why we either avoyde sinne, or performe holy duties, or frequent ordinances, is not because thereby we shall be justified, but that thereby we may glorifie God and Christ, and because therein wee have communion with Christ, and are made conformable unto him, and made more capable of more of Christ: when we goe to some stately Palace, where wee have appointed to meet some deare friend, whom we love with our whole soule, though we have never so much entertainment there when we come, yet if our love and our desire to see our friend be exceeding great, wee rather weepe then rejoyce, notwithstanding the feasts and buildings which we taste and see; prayer, hearing, the Word, the Lords Supper, are stately ordinances, and rich feasts; yet if we meet not Christ there, they are but dry breasts and barren wildernesses to a soule that loves Christ.

Secondly, Now the maine thing that hinders a poore soule from coming unto Christ, is, that it is not cleerely satisfied of Christs love and willingnesse to receive her: to this point therefore by the blessing of God I shall speake more largely, and as cleerely as the Lord shall inable mee; this therefore may be said to that point; art thou not satisfied of the love and willingnesse of Christ to receive thee. What can Christ say or doe more then he hath done? suppose Christ from Heaven should bid thee write downe what expressions soever thou wouldest or couldest invent, and bid thee call all the Sains in the whole world, and all the Angells in Heaven, and bid you consult together, and write downe the highest, fullest, cleerest, and largest expressions of love, and he will set his hand and seale to them, would that satisfie, surely God and Christ have done more, for the Holy Ghost comes not short of the expressions of love of whatsoever the Angells in Heaven could invent, thou hast his hand and seale to them in his Word, thou wouldest be a looser if thou shouldest make another draught of love for Christ to set his hand to, and take that instead of the expressions of love which he hath already ratified and confirmed by his Word, his Oath, his Seale, that thou mightest have strong consolation: Suppose that thou shouldest search the whole world to finde out the fondest, lovingest, and tenderest parent in the world, and when thou hast sound her, thou shouldest observe with what love, care, and bowells of affection shee carried her selfe towards her little Infant, how shee breakes her sleepe, and even her very heart when her childe is sicke, and never complaines of her paines and costs, and never thinkes shee can
doe or suffer enough for the little Infant: now if thou shalt say within thy selfe; O that I was sure that God loved me as much as this woman loves her childe, well, would that satisfie; then be satisfied, God loves thee more. Isa. 49.15. Can a woman forget her sucking childe, that she would not have compassion on the sonne of her wombe, yea they may forget, yet will not I forget thee: the Lord doth not say, can women, but a woman, any woman, finde out that woman which thou supposest is the most unlikely to forget her childe, yet God is more unlikely to forget thee; nay it is more possible that all the women of the world should forget their children then God; for though the question be put in the singular number, Can a woman; yet the answer is in the plurall, not she may, but they may, they all may. Further againe; Suppose thou wert at the solemnizing of a marriage of the lovingest couple in the whole world, and shouldest observe with how much joy and love the Bridegroome carried himselfe toward the Bride, even in the midst and height of all his nuptiall solemnities; wouldst thou not be satisfied if thou didst know that God did not onely love thee w • th tender love of compassion, with which the lovingest mother in the world loves her Infant, but with that love of complacencie which the Bridegroome beareth to, and with which he rejoyceth over his Bride: that his love was equall to their espousalls, then be satisfied, for God doth so; Isa. 62.5. And as a Bridegroome rejoyceth over his Bride, so shall thy God rejoyce over thee: Nay surely I may say, that the holiest Saint in the whole world, when by the clearest discoveries of Gods love unto him, his heart is most enflamed; nay further that the highest Angell in Heaven doth not love God so much, as God loves the poorest and meanest Saint in the whole world; for God so loved the world, it is such a sic, that there is no sicut for it, no that of the Angells unto him; nothing can expresse it to the full, save onely the greatnesse of the gift which he out of his love gave to, and for his people, even the Lord Jesus Christ.

To conclude, doe but consider what Christ hath done, and if thou art fully satisfied of that, thou canst have no cause to have the least doubt of his willingnesse to doe whatsoever is more to be done for thee; for that which is to be done is nothing in compar son of that which he hath already done for those that are his.

First, Nothing in respect of excellency, for the Apostle brings that in, He will much more give us all things: also for God to give thee Christ, is much more then to give thee Heaven; as to give thee Heaven is much more then to give thee all temporall blessings, Matth 6.33. If one that ought thee ten thousand pounds, should have payd thee nine thousand nine hundred ninety-nine, thou wouldest no whit doubt but he will pay thee the residue, especially If it stood upon the forfeiture of his credit; how much more shalt thou assure thy selfe of Gods Gods doing for thee whatsoever is behinde, since he hath already done so much.

Secondly, The great matter of difficulty is over; indeed it cost Christ deare, and God the Father deare to redeeme thee; God spared not his
owne Sonne; Christ spared not his bloud, nor his life; he suffered hunger, cold, and nakednesse, and reproach, the painfull and shamefull death of the Crosse to redeeme thee; but he lives for ever to make intercession for thee; he needs not rise off from his throne, nor put off his robes of glory to carry on the remainder of thy worke of salvation; he sits at the right hand of God to make intercession for thee; The Lord said unto my Lord, sit thou on my right hand untill I make thy enemies thy footstoole.

Thirdly, The great matter of wonder is over, also that a great and mighty Monarch should marry a poore wretched and diseased Woman, is a thing of great wonder; but its not so great a wonder that having married he should make her partakers of all the glory and riches of his Kingdome; nay indeed it was a wonder if he should nor. That Christ who is the Lord of glory should marry a poore sinfull soule is a wonder; but having married thee, that he should sanctifie thee, that he should present thee glorious, without spot or blemish, or any such thing, is no wonder; nay it was a wonder if he should still suffer thee to goe in rags, and never adorne thee with the Jewells of his grace, and set upon thy head the Crowne of glory were a wonder, therefore comfort your selfe with these truths: Now to him that hath done so much, and much more, be glory and honour for ever, Amen.
